docs.snippet: Michael R. Bloomberg may have flown to London to take part in a sting with Scotland Yard and the F.B.I. He may even have feared for his safety at times during the operation. But, he conceded yesterday, he is not likely to be assigned his own doubl...
docs.lead_paragraph: Michael R. Bloomberg may have flown to London to take part in a sting with Scotland Yard and the F.B.I. He may even have feared for his safety at times during the operation. But, he conceded yesterday, he is not likely to be assigned his own double-0 number anytime soon. ''Well, it wasn't exactly James Bond,'' Mr. Bloomberg told reporters after he testified in Federal District Court in Lower Manhattan against a man who was caught in that sting operation, Oleg Zezev, who is on trial on charges he hacked into Mr. Bloomberg's company's computer system and tried to extort money from him. ''But if you characterize it that way, there's a lot of similarity between Sean Connery and myself.''
docs.abstract: Mayor Michael R Bloomberg testifies in Federal District Court in Manhattan in trial of Oleg Zezev, who is charged with hacking into Bloomberg LP's computer system and trying to extort money from him; Bloomberg testifies about his role in sting operation; photo of Bloomberg, Zezev and Igor Yarimaka (M)

headline.main: Bloomberg Tells Trial Jury Of His Part In Taped Sting

Powell, who seized on a new audio tape believed to be of Osama bin Laden as evidence that the terrorist leader was ''in partnership with Iraq.'' A1

docs.lead_paragraph: Robert Mitchum, star of 1940's film noir classics, once commented on his reputation as a Hollywood bad boy: ''Booze, broads, it's all true. Make up more if you want.'' Benjamin Curtis, 22, an aspiring actor, is famous as the guy from the Dell computer commercials who says, ''Dude, you're gettin' a Dell!''
docs.abstract: Arrest of aspiring actor Benjamin Curtis on charge that he bought small bag of marijuana recalls 1948 arrest of actor Robert Mitchum on marijuana charge; photos (M)

headline.main: Dude's Future? On Web, He Could Look Up Mitchum

docs.snippet: Just months after being vilified by his peers in magazine articles and derided by the Hollywood grapevine as a mogul in decline, Harvey Weinstein and his New York-based ministudio, Miramax Films, are at the head of the pack, dominating the Academy...
docs.lead_paragraph: Just months after being vilified by his peers in magazine articles and derided by the Hollywood grapevine as a mogul in decline, Harvey Weinstein and his New York-based ministudio, Miramax Films, are at the head of the pack, dominating the Academy Awards race in a way that no single studio has done in more than half a century. That achievement is all the more significant because Miramax is not one of the major studios, like Warner Brothers or Columbia Pictures, but an indie start-up begun in 1979 by a pair of hustling, film-loving brothers from Queens, Harvey and Bob Weinstein. Their company grew steadily through the 80's, became an independent division of Disney in 1993 and after today has to be considered the equal of any of the major studios in Hollywood.
docs.abstract: Harvey Weinstein and his New York-based ministudio Miramax Films dominate Academy Awards race in way that no single studio has done in more than half century, just months after being vilified by his peers in magazine articles and derided by Hollywood grapevine as mogul in decline; achievement is all the more significant because Miramax is not one of major studios, but an indie startup begun in 1979 by pair of hustling, film-loving brothers from Queens, Harvey and Bob Weinstein; photo of Harvey Weinstein and Martin Scorcese; photos of scenes from Miramax films (L)

headline.main: It's Harvey Weinstein's Turn to Gloat

docs.snippet: The past is coming closer to Berlin. It had long been traditional for each Berlin International Film Festival to present several movies about the Holocaust and the Nazis. This continued after the festival moved in 2000 to the Potsdamer Platz, bare...
docs.lead_paragraph: The past is coming closer to Berlin. It had long been traditional for each Berlin International Film Festival to present several movies about the Holocaust and the Nazis. This continued after the festival moved in 2000 to the Potsdamer Platz, barely a half-mile from Hitler's bunker. But this year the program's political thrust involves more recent history. With Europe increasingly alarmed about illegal immigration, three movies in competition are addressing this issue. Not that the festival, now in its 53rd year, is necessarily political. Every year it also offers major American movies that use Berlin as launch pads for European releases. This year was no different, drawing an array of Hollywood stars. Yet Berlin's geography, history and even weather all conspire to link the Berlinale, as the festival is known, to the real world. In one of this year's most entertaining films, the real world is Berlin itself.
docs.abstract: Alan Riding reports on Berlinale, 53rd Berlin International Film Festival; photos (M)

headline.main: Grim Reality Dominates Berlinale Film Festival

docs.snippet: WILLIAM A. WISE, the longtime chairman and chief executive of the El Paso Corporation who helped transform it into the nation's largest natural gas pipeline company, announced plans yesterday to step down as the company's fortunes continue to sour...
docs.lead_paragraph: WILLIAM A. WISE, the longtime chairman and chief executive of the El Paso Corporation who helped transform it into the nation's largest natural gas pipeline company, announced plans yesterday to step down as the company's fortunes continue to sour from the collapse of Enron. Mr. Wise will remain chief executive until a successor is found and will retire as chairman at the end of the year. He had been struggling to restore investor confidence in El Paso after its energy-trading business fell apart last year and investors began questioning the company's accounting practices.
docs.abstract: William A Wise, longtime chairman and chief executive of El Paso Corp, announces plans to step down; will remain chief executive until successor is found and will retire as chairman at end of year; El Paso's financial problems detailed (Market Place column) (M)

headline.main: THE MARKETS: Market Place; The man who built up El Paso is leaving it in disarray.

docs.snippet: Surrounding Colin Powell's speech before the United Nations Security Council last week, the news media resurrected stunning images of Adlai Stevenson's legendary appearance in the same U.N. chamber during the Cuban missile crisis 41 years ago. Wha...
docs.lead_paragraph: Surrounding Colin Powell's speech before the United Nations Security Council last week, the news media resurrected stunning images of Adlai Stevenson's legendary appearance in the same U.N. chamber during the Cuban missile crisis 41 years ago. What the pictures quickly call to mind is that the cold war, America's previous age of anxiety, produced its own uniform etched in sharp angles. The early 1960's gave men lean suits that raised shoulders to the point of making them look nervously locked. What those years famously offered women was the miniskirt -- icy, androgynous, boxy -- onto which so many cultural apprehensions were projected.
docs.abstract: Fall 2003 fashion shows at Bryant Park reviewed; collections of Marc Jacobs and Kenneth Cole noted; photos (M)

headline.main: Review/Fashion; In an Age of Anxiety, Dodging Adulthood

docs.snippet: Lawyers for Clara Harris, the dentist accused of running over her husband in a jealous rage and killing him, are to present closing arguments on Wednesday. It will be their last chance to persuade the jury that David Harris's death under the wheel...
docs.lead_paragraph: Lawyers for Clara Harris, the dentist accused of running over her husband in a jealous rage and killing him, are to present closing arguments on Wednesday. It will be their last chance to persuade the jury that David Harris's death under the wheels of her car was an accident. Today, as the prosecution rested its case, the jury heard testimony from two witnesses who said they saw Clara Harris's silver S430 Mercedes-Benz run over David Harris at least three times July 24 last year at the Nassau Bay Hilton.
docs.abstract: Two prosecution witnesses testify at Houston, Tex, trial of Clara Harris, accused of murdering husband David Harris in July 2002 in jealous rage by running him over with car in hotel parking lot, that car ran over Harris's body several times; defendant claims husband's death was accidental (S)

headline.main: Car Struck Husband 3 Times, Jury Hears

docs.snippet: ''Chicago,'' a flashy adaptation of the Broadway musical about murdering floozies in the Roaring 20's, was the leader among four movies from Miramax Films that together dominated the nominations for the 75th annual Academy Awards, announced here t...
docs.lead_paragraph: ''Chicago,'' a flashy adaptation of the Broadway musical about murdering floozies in the Roaring 20's, was the leader among four movies from Miramax Films that together dominated the nominations for the 75th annual Academy Awards, announced here today, and propelled its New York-based studio into Hollywood's front ranks. That ''Chicago'' was nominated for best picture came as little surprise, and its total of 13 nominations was largely expected.
docs.abstract: Academy Award nominations are announced; Chicago is leader among four movies from Miramax films that together dominate nominations for 78th annual Academy Awards, and propel its New York-based studio into Hollywood's front ranks; Chicago gets 10 nominations, as does Gangs of New York, Martin Scorcese's violent epic; The Hours gets nine nominations; nominees listed; photos (L)

headline.main: 'Chicago' Tops Oscar Nominees; Miramax Lifted Into Front Ranks Among Studios
